comment._content: Changes since Bona Fide Travellers: The DBC. The tall electric lights (1892 until 1903-1910 sometime). Where is the Gunpowder office signage gone? Railings around the O'Connell monument. Electric trams. Straw hats! Light coloured clothes. Ladies on bikes.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: And as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] spotted, a dust cart spraying the street! We've never captured one of those in action before...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Per wikipedia, the Donnybrook tram was electrified from Jan 1899. I think the Hatch St. tram (via Westland Row) #22, electrified Jan 1900.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The DBC seems to have hoardings up at street level. I think it is not finished, and that this is Summer 1900.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
The clarity of the shot is remarkable with a great DOF!  You can see that the policeman is in full regalia with his "day" helmet and at his wrist is his "Duty" band showing that he is on duty.
Unusually the street traders on the near side of the Liffey are men!  On the far side the stall appears to be manned by a woman.  Right beside her a lady is dragging a reluctant urchin along to Clery's for his First Communion suit!  That just shows how good this shot is:-)
Neaves food was very much on sale when I was a nipper and I think right up to the late 50's at leaset

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: wrt shadows: The sun app says end of May or end of August - About 30 days from the solstice either side. (Assuming that the time is 14:43).

comment.author: 29809546@N00

comment._content: 9th shot in this gallery: Wallace Bros Coal and Coke, 2 D'Olier St.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
With regard to the design of the DBC building, a Keystone-Kops account of a small fire at the DBC restaurant at 33 Dame Street on Sept 6 1898 ('FIre and Fiasco in the City - Overzealous Citizens - Smash fire escape') says
The kitchen, as in most modern establishments carrying on a restaurant business, like the Dublin Bakery [or should it be Bread?] Company does, is situated at the top of the house, with a view to preserve the dinner and luncheon rooms from too high a temperature
so I assume the one in the picture would be designed on the same principles, with the kitchens at the top. Would food be delivered by means of a movable boudoir? I was hoping streetview might show reveal something interesting at 33 Dame Street, but it looks as if the facade has been modernised, unlike some of its neighbours. Streetview. DBC also had tea rooms at Kingstown station, described as 'new' in an account of a fire on June 25th 1900

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Freeman's Tuesday 21st August 1900

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]  Maybe a dumb waiter caused the 'small fire' mentioned in your account above. :)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Ha ha. A 'movable cuisine', perhaps. A dumb cook, more like, who had put a mixture of beeswax and turpentine on the fire to heat. Details here [includes references to 'meddlesome boys' and a 'frightened quartette of females'] I wonder what recipe requires beeswax and turpentine? If I'd read that it might put me off ever using DBC's Dame Street luncheon rooms.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: To answer my own question, beeswax and turpentine are mixed to make beeswax polish. The cook obviously hadn't seen this website

comment.author: 59941010@N06

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Thanks for the link to the fire article. Very entertaining read. Possibly because of the repeated (if bizarre in today's terms) "naming and shaming" of the hapless citizens who are held up to mockery for their differing levels of involvement. One of the "frightened quartette" of ladies mentioned likely went home to recount her tale in Camden Street.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Wonderful article showing that the forces of law and order are not only brave but versatile as well.  134B must have been off his beat if he did not give his name to the intrepid reporter!  The Garda museum might be able to identify the officers concerned from the old DMP Register in its custody!  Both numbers are still alive and active in the nearby Pearse Street station!

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Apologies to all Joyceans - On the last picture of the DBC I misquoted James Joyce's Ulysses. The quotation (from 'Wandering Rocks') is "We call it D.B.C. because they have damn bad cakes. O, but you missed Dedalus on Hamlet". I'm just in my annual reading of the novel.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Using the contemporary weather reports to date photos seems sensible and reliable to me. Why not? Or at least to confirm dates. But if there were anticyclones centred over Europe it would surely produce south-easterly (ie warm and dry) winds in Ireland - hence the summer clothes on the folk and the sprinkling water-cart. Also there is a convenient large flag just to the right of Nelson's Pillar which seems to show a stiff breeze from the south-east - if Sackville Street runs roughly NNW-SSE. Hot and cross virtual sticky buns at the DBC!

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Freeman's reported 'constant wet weather for the last fortnight' on 15th August 1900, which was endangering the harvest, but on the 17th 'propitious weather' was reported at Ballyboden Cottage Show and a cricket match between Richmond Asylum and The Druids was played in 'glorious weather'. On the same say it was reported that a labourer named John Lee was taken to Jervis street hospital and diagnosed as suffering from 'heat apoplexy'. Spectators at Dundrum sports earlier in the week had enjoyed 'scorching hot' weather. A report under the heading 'Yachting' on Monday 20th says 'Saturday, although a suitable and glorious day for all sports, was a little too fine for yachting, and out of a big list of sailing fixtures at Howth and Kingstown but one race was completed. The light breeze of the forenoon failed almost altogether in the afternoon, and all the racers were hopelessly becalmed for some hours'.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I think the only thing stopping us until now has been getting accurate reports, but you seem to have solved that one.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: In its daily 'Shipping Intelligence' column, Freeman's has a one-line summary of the previous day's Dublin weather, with wind direction & strength, one or two words of general description (e.g. fine, showery) and barometric pressure. I've put August 1890's entries on a spreadsheet The observations seem to agree the other data we have - the window of fine weather was from the 16th to the 20th or 21st.. Please ignore.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Dublin weather August 1900 A report on the Greystones tennis tournament backs this up (i.e. that the fine spell began on the 11th) - "This tournament continued on Saturday, when the weather favourably contrasted with that of the previous days of the tournament" (although I'm not convinced it was played on consecutive days). The tournament had begun a week earlier but "Owing to recent heavy rain the courts were somewhat soft".

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Well, 20th was where the shadows put it, but again, that's by eye, rather than measured. It could be a couple of weeks either side. The fruit barrow, being square, gives a pretty clear sun direction and height though.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I wonder how many consecutive dry days before the street sprinkler is required to damp down the dust?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] I wouldn't argue with any of that.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
I've given up waiting for a Limerick, so here's the result when The street-sprinkler recently set his Muse to work, with the following charming result:-
Throughout the hot and dusty day The sprinkling sprinkler sprinks its way, And sprinkles sprinklings up and down The sprinkful precincts of the town. In vain have sprinkled ladies swore At crossings sprinkly sprinkled o'er; In vain the sprightly sprinkling hoots Who sees the sprinkler sprink his boots; That sprinkling sprinkler sprinkles on Until its sprinkling sprink is done, Nor pauses for a curse or thank Until its final sprink is sprank.
 (The Preston Guardian, Saturday, August 23, 1879)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I can't quite make out what is in the window of Hopkins & Hopkins. The advert placed in Freemans on 17th August 1900 tells us what we can expect to see in a few days - A massive solid silver tray and table lamp, a handsome gold chain bracelet and a solid silver Irish 2-handled challenge cup. Hopkins & Hopkins advert

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Of course our musings aren't helped by the fact that I've got a typo in my first shadow post which I've then repeated later. It's around the 20th of July, not August.

comment._content: The Dublin Bread Company Limerick It's almost a quarter to three We could do with a nice cup of tea. Let's sprinkle our feet As we stroll up the street - For hot buns at the new D. B. C.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] There's no time of day that could make it the 20th of August. The sun is too high.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I knew you'd come up trumps! Meanwhile, Dublin weather July 1900 Not as clear-cut as August.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Thank you! I had "tarts" instead of ''buns" at first ...

Re The Weather - Thursday 19/7/1900 is looking good - "fine, SE breezes" and it hasn't rained in Dublin since 3 July ... good enough reason for a sprinkle.  Also the River Liffey looks low - undoubtedly the tide.  Aha! That gives me an idea - the Dublin tide times for July 1900 (at 14:43 -ish).  Where to find them ... ?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  High water at Dublin for July 1900
July 4  03:25 & 15:48
July 5  04:12 & 16:38
July 6  05:08 & 17:36
July 7  06:05 & 18:37
July 10 09:09 & 21:37
July 1210:42 & 23:04
July 14 12:00 & 00:10
July 17 02:08 & 14:33
July 18 02:57 & 15:23
July 19 03:51 & 16:18
July 23 08:17 & 20:50
July 26 10:53 & 23:12
July 27 11:29 & 23:46
July 28 12:00 & 00:05
July 30 01:00 & 13:15

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I can't guarantee it from a still, but it looks like the tide is coming in, not going out, which would put it at less than six and a half hours from high water, or at a guess from the picture, about three hours before high water, which could really only be about the 20th or 21st, but that doesn't match the breeze direction, which looks easterly. It can't be the 22nd because there's too many shops open for a sunday. Let's have another look at the shadow machine...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Of course, without daylight saving, what I'm seeing as three o'clock on the solar calculator would have been called two o'clock back then, so the tide could conceivably be 16:18.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: At this stage though, I'm starting to suspect an hour earlier in late June. The lack of readable clocks makes this difficult. If the clock really said 14:43, that'd make it 15:43 in today's money, and there's no way it's that late. If we therefore ignore the clock and go just with the shadows, it's 14:00 (new time - 13:00 1900-time) on the 26th June.
